speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: New plays and maidenheads are near akin—
Much follow’d both, for both much money gi’n,
If they stand sound and well; and a good play
(Whose modest scenes blush on his marriage-day,
And shake to lose his honor) is like her
That after holy tie and first night’s stir,
Yet still is modesty, and still retains
More of the maid to sight than husband’s pains.
We pray our play may be so; for I am sure
It has a noble breeder and a pure,
A learned, and a poet never went
More famous yet ’twixt Po and silver Trent.
Chaucer (of all admir’d) the story gives;
There constant to eternity it lives.
If we let fall the nobleness of this,
And the first sound this child hear be a hiss,
How will it shake the bones of that good man,
And make him cry from under ground, “O, fan
From me the witless chaff of such a writer
That blasts my bays and my fam’d works makes lighter
Than Robin Hood!” This is the fear we bring;
For to say truth, it were an endless thing,
And too ambitious, to aspire to him,
Weak as we are, and almost breathless swim
In this deep water. Do but you hold out
Your helping hands, and we shall tack about
And something do to save us. You shall hear
Scenes, though below his art, may yet appear
Worth two hours’ travail. To his bones sweet sleep!
Content to you! If this play do not keep
A little dull time from us, we perceive
Our losses fall so thick we must needs leave.

stagedir.dir: Enter Hymen with a torch burning; a Boy, in a white robe, before, singing and strewing flow’rs; after Hymen, a Nymph, encompass’d in her tresses, bearing a wheaten garland; then Theseus, between two other Nymphs with wheaten chaplets an their heads; then Hippolyta, the bride, led by Pirithous, and another holding a garland over her head (her tresses likewise hanging; after her, Emilia, holding up her train; Artesius and Attendants.

scene.line: Roses, their sharp spines being gone,
Not royal in their smells alone,
But in their hue;
Maiden pinks, of odor faint,
Daisies smell-less, yet most quaint,
And sweet thyme true;
Primrose, first-born child of Ver,
Merry spring-time’s harbinger,
With her bells dim;
Oxlips in their cradles growing,
Marigolds on death-beds blowing,
Larks’-heels trim;
All dear Nature’s children sweet,
Lie ’fore bride and bridegroom’s feet.
Blessing their sense;
Not an angel of the air,
Bird melodious, or bird fair,
Is absent hence.
The crow, the sland’rous cuckoo, nor
The boding raven, nor chough hoar,
Nor chatt’ring pie,
May on our bridehouse perch or sing,
Or with them any discord bring,
But from it fly.

stagedir.dir: Enter three Queens, in black, with veils stain’d, with imperial crowns.

scene.line: O, help now!
Our cause cries for your knee.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: If you grant not
My sister her petition, in that force,
With that celerity and nature, which
She makes it in, from henceforth I’ll not dare
To ask you any thing, nor be so hardy
Ever to take a husband.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Pray stand up.
I am entreating of myself to do
That which you kneel to have me. Pirithous,
Lead on the bride; get you and pray the gods
For success and return; omit not any thing
In the pretended celebration. Queens,
Follow your soldier.
Farewell, my beauteous sister. Pirithous,
Keep the feast full, bate not an hour on’t.

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: Sir,
I’ll follow you at heels; the feast’s solemnity
Shall want till your return.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Cousin, I charge you
Boudge not from Athens. We shall be returning
Ere you can end this feast, of which I pray you
Make no abatement. Once more, farewell all.

speech.speaker: 1. QUEEN.
speech.line: Thus dost thou still make good
The tongue o’ th’ world.

speech.speaker: 2. QUEEN.
speech.line: And earn’st a deity
Equal with Mars.

speech.speaker: 3. QUEEN.
speech.line: If not above him, for
Thou being but mortal makest affections bend
To godlike honors; they themselves, some say,
Groan under such a mast’ry.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: As we are men
Thus should we do, being sensually subdu’d
We lose our human title. Good cheer, ladies.
Now turn we towards your comforts.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Dear Palamon, dearer in love than blood,
And our prime cousin, yet unhard’ned in
The crimes of nature—let us leave the city
Thebes, and the temptings in’t, before we further
Sully our gloss of youth:
And here to keep in abstinence we shame
As in incontinence; for not to swim
I’ th’ aid o’ th’ current were almost to sink,
At least to frustrate striving, and to follow
The common stream, ’twould bring us to an eddy
Where we should turn or drown; if labor through,
Our gain but life and weakness.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Your advice
Is cried up with example. What strange ruins,
Since first we went to school, may we perceive
Walking in Thebes! Scars and bare weeds
The gain o’ th’ martialist, who did propound
To his bold ends honor and golden ingots,
Which though he won, he had not; and now flurted
By peace, for whom he fought, who then shall offer
To Mars’s so scorn’d altar? I do bleed
When such I meet, and wish great Juno would
Resume her ancient fit of jealousy
To get the soldier work, that peace might purge
For her repletion, and retain anew
Her charitable heart, now hard, and harsher
Than strife or war could be.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Are you not out?
Meet you no ruin but the soldier in
The cranks and turns of Thebes? You did begin
As if you met decays of many kinds.
Perceive you none that do arouse your pity
But th’ unconsider’d soldier?

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Yes, I pity
Decays where e’er I find them, but such most
That sweating in an honorable toil
Are paid with ice to cool ’em.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: ’Tis not this
I did begin to speak of. This is virtue
Of no respect in Thebes. I spake of Thebes,
How dangerous, if we will keep our honors,
It is for our residing; where every evil
Hath a good color; where ev’ry seeming good’s
A certain evil; where not to be ev’n jump
As they are, here were to be strangers, and
Such things to be, mere monsters.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: ’Tis in our power
(Unless we fear that apes can tutor’s) to
Be masters of our manners. What need I
Affect another’s gait, which is not catching
Where there is faith? Or to be fond upon
Another’s way of speech, when by mine own
I may be reasonably conceiv’d; sav’d too,
Speaking it truly? Why am I bound
By any generous bond to follow him
Follows his tailor, haply so long until
The follow’d make pursuit? Or let me know
Why mine own barber is unblest, with him
My poor chin too, for ’tis not scissor’d just
To such a favorite’s glass? What canon is there
That does command my rapier from my hip,
To dangle’t in my hand, or to go tiptoe
Before the street be foul? Either I am
The forehorse in the team, or I am none
That draw i’ th’ sequent trace. These poor slight sores
Need not a plantin; that which rips my bosom
Almost to th’ heart’s—

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Our uncle Creon.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: He,
A most unbounded tyrant, whose successes
Makes heaven unfear’d, and villainy assured
Beyond its power there’s nothing; almost puts
Faith in a fever, and deifies alone
Voluble chance; who only attributes
The faculties of other instruments
To his own nerves and act; commands men service,
And what they win in’t, boot and glory; one
That fears not to do harm; good, dares not. Let
The blood of mine that’s sib to him be suck’d
From me with leeches! Let them break and fall
Off me with that corruption!

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Clear-spirited cousin,
Let’s leave his court, that we may nothing share
Of his loud infamy; for our milk
Will relish of the pasture, and we must
Be vile, or disobedient—not his kinsmen
In blood unless in quality.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Nothing truer.
I think the echoes of his shames have deaf’d
The ears of heav’nly justice. Widows’ cries
Descend again into their throats, and have not
Due audience of the gods.

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: No further.

speech.speaker: HIP.
speech.line: Sir, farewell. Repeat my wishes
To our great lord, of whose success I dare not
Make any timorous question; yet I wish him
Excess and overflow of power, and’t might be,
To dure ill-dealing fortune. Speed to him,
Store never hurts good governors.

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: Though I know
His ocean needs not my poor drops, yet they
Must yield their tribute there. My precious maid,
Those best affections that the heavens infuse
In their best-temper’d pieces, keep enthron’d
In your dear heart!

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Thanks, sir. Remember me
To our all-royal brother, for whose speed
The great Bellona I’ll solicit; and
Since in our terrene state petitions are not
Without gifts understood, I’ll offer to her
What I shall be advis’d she likes. Our hearts
Are in his army, in his tent.

speech.speaker: HIP.
speech.line: In ’s bosom.
We have been soldiers, and we cannot weep
When our friends don their helms, or put to sea,
Or tell of babes broach’d on the lance, or women
That have sod their infants in (and after eat them)
The brine they wept at killing ’em. Then if
You stay to see of us such spinsters, we
Should hold you here forever.

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: Peace be to you
As I pursue this war, which shall be then
Beyond further requiring.

stagedir.dir: Then enter Theseus, victor, with his Lords.
Enter Herald with Attendants bearing Palamon and Arcite on two hearses.

scene.scenelocation: Another part of a field before Thebes.

stagedir.dir: Music. Enter the Queens with the hearses of their Knights in a funeral solemnity, etc.

scene.line: Urns and odors bring away,
Vapors, sighs, darken the day;
Our dole more deadly looks than dying;
Balms, and gums, and heavy cheers,
Sacred vials fill’d with tears,
And clamors through the wild air flying!
Come all sad and solemn shows,
That are quick-ey’d pleasure’s foes!
We convent nought else but woes:
We convent, etc.

speech.speaker: 3. QUEEN.
speech.line: This funeral path brings to your household’s grave:
Joy seize on you again! Peace sleep with him!

speech.speaker: 2. QUEEN.
speech.line: And this to yours.

speech.speaker: 1. QUEEN.
speech.line: Yours this way. Heavens lend
A thousand differing ways to one sure end.

speech.speaker: 3. QUEEN.
speech.line: This world’s a city full of straying streets,
And death’s the market-place, where each one meets.

scene.scenelocation: Athens. A garden, with a prison in the background.

speech.speaker: WOOER.
speech.line: I have, sir. Here she comes.

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: Your friend and I have chanc’d to name you here, upon the old business. But no more of that now; so soon as the court hurry is over, we will have an end of it. I’ th’ mean time, look tenderly to the two prisoners. I can tell you they are princes.

speech.speaker: DAUGH.
speech.line: These strewings are for their chamber. ’Tis pity they are in prison, and ’twere pity they should be out. I do think they have patience to make any adversity asham’d. The prison itself is proud of ’em; and they have all the world in their chamber.

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: They are fam’d to be a pair of absolute men.

speech.speaker: DAUGH.
speech.line: By my troth, I think fame but stammers ’em, they stand a grise above the reach of report.

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: I heard them reported in the battle to be the only doers.

speech.speaker: DAUGH.
speech.line: Nay, most likely, for they are noble suff’rers. I marvel how they would have look’d had they been victors, that with such a constant nobility enforce a freedom out of bondage, making misery their mirth, and affliction a toy to jest at.

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: Do they so?

speech.speaker: DAUGH.
speech.line: It seems to me they have no more sense of their captivity than I of ruling Athens. They eat well, look merrily, discourse of many things, but nothing of their own restraint and disasters. Yet sometime a divided sigh, martyr’d as ’twere i’ th’ deliverance, will break from one of them; when the other presently gives it so sweet a rebuke that I could wish myself a sigh to be so chid, or at least a sigher to be comforted.

speech.speaker: WOOER.
speech.line: I never saw ’em.

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: The Duke himself came privately in the night, and so did they. What the reason of it is, I know not.

stagedir.dir: Enter Palamon, and Arcite in prison.

scene.line: And after death our spirits shall be led
To those that love eternally. Speak on, sir.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: This garden has a world of pleasures in’t.
What flow’r is this?

speech.speaker: WOMAN.
speech.line: ’Tis call’d narcissus, madam.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: That was a fair boy certain, but a fool
To love himself. Were there not maids enough?

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Pray forward.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Yes.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Or were they all hard-hearted?

speech.speaker: WOMAN.
speech.line: They could not be to one so fair.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Thou wouldst not.

speech.speaker: WOMAN.
speech.line: I think I should not, madam.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: That’s a good wench!
But take heed to your kindness though.

speech.speaker: WOMAN.
speech.line: Why, madam?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Men are mad things.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Will ye go forward, cousin?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Canst not thou work such flowers in silk, wench?

speech.speaker: WOMAN.
speech.line: Yes.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: I’ll have a gown full of ’em, and of these:
This is a pretty color, will’t not do
Rarely upon a skirt, wench?

speech.speaker: WOMAN.
speech.line: Dainty, madam.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Cousin, cousin, how do you, sir? Why, Palamon!

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Never till now I was in prison, Arcite.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Why, what’s the matter, man?

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Behold, and wonder!
By heaven, she is a goddess.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Ha!

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Do reverence;
She is a goddess, Arcite.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Of all flow’rs
Methinks a rose is best.

speech.speaker: WOMAN.
speech.line: Why, gentle madam?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: It is the very emblem of a maid;
For when the west wind courts her gently,
How modestly she blows, and paints the sun
With her chaste blushes! When the north comes near her,
Rude and impatient, then, like chastity,
She locks her beauties in her bud again,
And leaves him to base briers.

speech.speaker: WOMAN.
speech.line: Yet, good madam,
Sometimes her modesty will blow so far she falls for’t.
A maid, if she have any honor, would be loath
To take example by her.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Thou art wanton.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: She is wondrous fair.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: She is all the beauty extant.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: The sun grows high, let’s walk in. Keep these flowers,
We’ll see how near art can come near their colors.
I am wondrous merry-hearted, I could laugh now.

speech.speaker: WOMAN.
speech.line: I could lie down, I am sure.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: And take one with you?

speech.speaker: WOMAN.
speech.line: That’s as we bargain, madam.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Well, agree then.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: No more; the keeper’s coming. I shall live
To knock thy brains out with my shackles.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Do.

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: By your leave, gentlemen.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Now, honest keeper?

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: Lord Arcite, you must presently to th’ Duke;
The cause I know not yet.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: I am ready, keeper.

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: Prince Palamon, I must awhile bereave you
Of your fair cousin’s company.

scene.line: How now, keeper,
Where’s Arcite?

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: Banish’d. Prince Pirithous
Obtained his liberty; but never more,
Upon his oath and life, must he set foot
Upon this kingdom.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Farewell, kind window.
May rude wind never hurt thee! O my lady,
If ever thou hast felt what sorrow was,
Dream how I suffer!—Come; now bury me.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Banish’d the kingdom? ’Tis a benefit,
A mercy I must thank ’em for; but banish’d
The free enjoying of that face I die for—
O, ’twas a studied punishment, a death
Beyond imagination! Such a vengeance
That were I old and wicked, all my sins
Could never pluck upon me. Palamon!
Thou hast the start now; thou shalt stay and see
Her bright eyes break each morning ’gainst thy window,
And let in life into thee; thou shalt feed
Upon the sweetness of a noble beauty,
That nature nev’r exceeded, nor nev’r shall.
Good gods! What happiness has Palamon!
Twenty to one, he’ll come to speak to her,
And if she be as gentle as she’s fair,
I know she’s his; he has a tongue will tame tempests,
And make the wild rocks wanton. Come what can come,
The worst is death: I will not leave the kingdom.
I know mine own is but a heap of ruins,
And no redress there. If I go, he has her.
I am resolv’d another shape shall make me,
Or end my fortunes. Either way, I am happy:
I’ll see her, and be near her, or no more.

stagedir.dir: Enter four Country People, and one with a garland before them.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: This is an offer’d opportunity
I durst not wish for. Well I could have wrestled,
The best men call’d it excellent; and run
Swifter than wind upon a field of corn,
Curling the wealthy ears, never flew. I’ll venture,
And in some poor disguise be there. Who knows
Whether my brows may not be girt with garlands,
And happiness prefer me to a place
Where I may ever dwell in sight of her?

speech.speaker: DAUGH.
speech.line: Why should I love this gentleman? ’Tis odds
He never will affect me. I am base,
My father the mean keeper of his prison,
And he a prince. To marry him is hopeless;
To be his whore is witless. Out upon’t!
What pushes are we wenches driven to
When fifteen once has found us! First, I saw him:
I, seeing, thought he was a goodly man;
He has as much to please a woman in him
(If he please to bestow it so) as ever
These eyes yet look’d on. Next, I pitied him;
And so would any young wench o’ my conscience
That ever dream’d, or vow’d her maidenhead
To a young handsome man. Then, I lov’d him,
Extremely lov’d him, infinitely lov’d him;
And yet he had a cousin, fair as he too;
But in my heart was Palamon, and there,
Lord, what a coil he keeps! To hear him
Sing in an evening, what a heaven it is!
And yet his songs are sad ones. Fairer spoken
Was never gentleman. When I come in
To bring him water in a morning, first
He bows his noble body, then salutes me thus:
“Fair gentle maid, good morrow. May thy goodness
Get thee a happy husband!” Once he kiss’d me—
I lov’d my lips the better ten days after.
Would he would do so ev’ry day! He grieves much,
And me as much to see his misery.
What should I do to make him know I love him,
For I would fain enjoy him? Say I ventur’d
To set him free? What says the law then?
Thus much for law or kindred! I will do it,
And this night, or tomorrow, he shall love me.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: You have done worthily. I have not seen,
Since Hercules, a man of tougher sinews.
What e’er you are, you run the best, and wrastle,
That these times can allow.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: I am proud to please you.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: What country bred you?

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: This; but far off, prince.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Are you a gentleman?

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: My father said so;
And to those gentle uses gave me life.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Are you his heir?

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: His youngest, sir.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Your father
Sure is a happy sire then. What proves you?

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: A little of all noble qualities:
I could have kept a hawk, and well have hollow’d
To a deep cry of dogs; I dare not praise
My feat in horsemanship, yet they that knew me
Would say it was my best piece; last, and greatest,
I would be thought a soldier.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: You are perfect.

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: Upon my soul, a proper man!

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: He is so.

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: How do you like him, lady?

speech.speaker: HIP.
speech.line: I admire him;
I have not seen so young a man so noble
(If he say true) of his sort.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Believe
His mother was a wondrous handsome woman,
His face, methinks, goes that way.

speech.speaker: HIP.
speech.line: But his body
And fiery mind illustrate a brave father.

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: Mark how his virtue, like a hidden sun,
Breaks through his baser garments.

speech.speaker: HIP.
speech.line: He’s well got sure.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: What made you seek this place, sir?

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Noble Theseus,
To purchase name, and do my ablest service
To such a well-found wonder as thy worth,
For only in thy court, of all the world,
Dwells fair-ey’d honor.

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: All his words are worthy.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Sir, we are much indebted to your travel,
Nor shall you lose your wish. Pirithous,
Dispose of this fair gentleman.

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: Thanks, Theseus.—
What e’er you are, y’ are mine, and I shall give you
To a most noble service—to this lady,
This bright young virgin. Pray observe her goodness.
You have honor’d her fair birthday with your virtues,
And as your due y’ are hers. Kiss her fair hand, sir.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Sir, y’ are a noble giver. Dearest beauty,
Thus let me seal my vow’d faith.
When your servant
(Your most unworthy creature) but offends you,
Command him die, he shall.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: That were too cruel.
If you deserve well, sir, I shall soon see’t.
Y’ are mine, and somewhat better than your rank I’ll use you.

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: I’ll see you furnish’d, and because you say
You are a horseman, I must needs entreat you
This afternoon to ride, but ’tis a rough one.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: I like him better, prince, I shall not then
Freeze in my saddle.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Sweet, you must be ready,
And you, Emilia, and you, friend, and all,
Tomorrow, by the sun, to do observance
To flow’ry May, in Dian’s wood. Wait well, sir,
Upon your mistress. Emily, I hope
He shall not go afoot.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: That were a shame, sir,
While I have horses.—Take your choice, and what
You want at any time, let me but know it.
If you serve faithfully, I dare assure you
You’ll find a loving mistress.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: If I do not,
Let me find that my father ever hated,
Disgrace and blows.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Go lead the way; you have won it.
It shall be so; you shall receive all dues
Fit for the honor you have won; ’twere wrong else.
Sister, beshrew my heart, you have a servant
That if I were a woman, would be master,
But you are wise.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: I hope too wise for that, sir.

speech.speaker: DAUGH.
speech.line: Let all the dukes and all the devils roar,
He is at liberty! I have ventur’d for him,
And out I have brought him to a little wood
A mile hence. I have sent him where a cedar,
Higher than all the rest, spreads like a plane
Fast by a brook, and there he shall keep close
Till I provide him files and food, for yet
His iron bracelets are not off. O Love,
What a stout-hearted child thou art! My father
Durst better have endur’d cold iron than done it.
I love him beyond love and beyond reason,
Or wit, or safety. I have made him know it.
I care not, I am desperate. If the law
Find me, and then condemn me for’t, some wenches,
Some honest-hearted maids, will sing my dirge,
And tell to memory my death was noble,
Dying almost a martyr. That way he takes
I purpose is my way too. Sure he cannot
Be so unmanly as to leave me here.
If he do, maids will not so easily
Trust men again. And yet he has not thank’d me
For what I have done; no, not so much as kiss’d me;
And that, methinks, is not so well; nor scarcely
Could I persuade him to become a freeman,
He made such scruples of the wrong he did
To me and to my father. Yet I hope,
When he considers more, this love of mine
Will take more root within him. Let him do
What he will with me, so he use me kindly,
For use me so he shall, or I’ll proclaim him,
And to his face, no man. I’ll presently
Provide him necessaries, and pack my clothes up,
And where there is a path of ground I’ll venture,
So he be with me. By him, like a shadow,
I’ll ever dwell. Within this hour the whoobub
Will be all o’er the prison. I am then
Kissing the man they look for. Farewell, father;
Get many more such prisoners and such daughters,
And shortly you may keep yourself. Now to him!

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: The Duke has lost Hippolyta; each took
A several land. This is a solemn rite
They owe bloom’d May, and the Athenians pay it
To th’ heart of ceremony. O queen Emilia,
Fresher than May, sweeter
Than her gold buttons on the boughs, or all
Th’ enamell’d knacks o’ th’ mead or garden! Yea
(We challenge too) the bank of any nymph,
That makes the stream seem flowers! Thou, O jewel
O’ th’ wood, o’ th’ world, hast likewise blest a place
With thy sole presence. In thy rumination
That I, poor man, might eftsoons come between
And chop on some cold thought! Thrice-blessed chance,
To drop on such a mistress, expectation
Most guiltless on’t. Tell me, O Lady Fortune
(Next after Emily my sovereign), how far
I may be proud. She takes strong note of me,
Hath made me near her; and this beauteous morn
(The prim’st of all the year) presents me with
A brace of horses; two such steeds might well
Be by a pair of kings back’d, in a field
That their crowns’ titles tried. Alas, alas,
Poor cousin Palamon, poor prisoner, thou
So little dream’st upon my fortune that
Thou think’st thyself the happier thing to be
So near Emilia. Me thou deem’st at Thebes,
And therein wretched, although free. But if
Thou knew’st my mistress breath’d on me, and that
I ear’d her language, liv’d in her eye, O coz,
What passion would enclose thee!

stagedir.dir: Enter Palamon, as out of a bush, with his shackles; bends his fist at Arcite.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: You hear the horns:
Enter your musit, lest this match between ’s
Be cross’d ere met. Give me your hand, farewell.
I’ll bring you every needful thing. I pray you
Take comfort and be strong.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Pray hold your promise;
And do the deed with a bent brow. Most certain
You love me not; be rough with me, and pour
This oil out of your language. By this air,
I could for each word give a cuff, my stomach
Not reconcil’d by reason.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Plainly spoken,
Yet pardon me hard language. When I spur
My horse, I chide him not; content and anger
In me have but one face.

scene.scenelocation: Another part of the forest near Athens.
Another part of the forest near Athens.

stagedir.dir: Enter Arcite with meat, wine, and files.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Arcite?

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: The same. I have brought you food and files.
Come forth and fear not, here’s no Theseus.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Nor none so honest, Arcite.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: That’s no matter,
We’ll argue that hereafter. Come, take courage,
You shall not die thus beastly. Here, sir, drink—
I know you are faint—then I’ll talk further with you.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Arcite, thou mightst now poison me.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: I might;
But I must fear you first. Sit down, and good now
No more of these vain parleys; let us not,
Having our ancient reputation with us,
Make talk for fools and cowards. To your health, etc.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Do.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Pray sit down then, and let me entreat you
By all the honesty and honor in you,
No mention of this woman. ’Twill disturb us,
We shall have time enough.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Well, sir, I’ll pledge you.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Drink a good hearty draught, it breeds good blood, man.
Do not you feel it thaw you?

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Stay, I’ll tell you
After a draught or two more.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Spare it not,
The Duke has more, coz. Eat now.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Yes.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: I am glad
You have so good a stomach.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: I am gladder
I have so good meat to’t.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Is’t not mad lodging
Here in the wild woods, cousin?

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Yes, for them
That have wild consciences.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: How tastes your victuals?
Your hunger needs no sauce, I see.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Not much.
But if it did, yours is too tart, sweet cousin.
What is this?

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Venison.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: ’Tis a lusty meat.
Give me more wine. Here, Arcite, to the wenches
We have known in our days! The Lord Steward’s daughter—
Do you remember her?

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: After you, coz.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: She lov’d a black-hair’d man.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: She did so; well, sir?

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: And I have heard some call him Arcite, and—

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Out with’t, faith!

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: She met him in an arbor:
What did she there, coz? Play o’ th’ virginals?

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Something she did, sir.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Made her groan a month for’t;
Or two, or three, or ten.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: The Marshal’s sister
Had her share too, as I remember, cousin,
Else there be tales abroad. You’ll pledge her?

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Yes.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: A pretty brown wench ’tis. There was a time
When young men went a-hunting, and a wood,
And a broad beech; and thereby hangs a tale.
Heigh-ho!

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: For Emily, upon my life! Fool,
Away with this strain’d mirth! I say again,
That sigh was breath’d for Emily. Base cousin,
Dar’st thou break first?

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: You are wide.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: By heaven and earth,
There’s nothing in thee honest.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Then I’ll leave you;
You are a beast now.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: As thou mak’st me, traitor!

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: There’s all things needful, files and shirts and perfumes.
I’ll come again some two hours hence and bring
That that shall quiet all.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: A sword and armor.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Fear me not. You are now too foul; farewell.
Get off your trinkets, you shall want nought.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Sirrah—

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: I’ll hear no more.

scene.scenelocation: Another part of the forest near Athens.
scene.line: “For I’ll cut my green coat a foot above my knee,
And I’ll clip my yellow locks an inch below mine e’e.
Hey, nonny, nonny, nonny.
He s’ buy me a white cut, forth for to ride,
And I’ll go seek him through the world that is so wide.
Hey, nonny, nonny, nonny.”
O for a prick now, like a nightingale,
To put my breast against! I shall sleep like a top else.

speech.speaker: SCHOOL.
speech.line: Fie, fie,
What tediosity and disensanity
Is here among ye! Have my rudiments
Been labor’d so long with ye, milk’d unto ye,
And by a figure, even the very plum-broth
And marrow of my understanding laid upon ye,
And do you still cry, “Where?” and “How?” and “Wherefore?”
You most coarse frieze capacities, ye jane judgments,
Have I said, “Thus let be,” and “There let be,”
And “Then let be,” and no man understand me?
Proh Deum, medius fidius, ye are all dunces!
For why, here stand I; here the Duke comes; there are you,
Close in the thicket. The Duke appears, I meet him
And unto him I utter learned things,
And many figures; he hears, and nods, and hums,
And then cries, “Rare!” and I go forward. At length
I fling my cap up; mark there! Then do you,
As once did Meleager and the boar,
Break comely out before him; like true lovers,
Cast yourselves in a body decently,
And sweetly, by a figure, trace and turn, boys.

speech.speaker: 1. COUN.
speech.line: And sweetly we will do it, Master Gerrold.

speech.speaker: 2. COUN.
speech.line: Draw up the company. Where’s the taborer?

speech.speaker: 3. COUN.
speech.line: Why, Timothy!

speech.speaker: TABORER.
speech.line: Here, my mad boys, have at ye!

speech.speaker: SCHOOL.
speech.line: But I say, where’s their women?

speech.speaker: 4. COUN.
speech.line: Here’s Friz and Maudline.

speech.speaker: 2. COUN.
speech.line: And little Luce with the white legs, and bouncing Barbary.

speech.speaker: 1. COUN.
speech.line: And freckled Nell—that never fail’d her master.

speech.speaker: SCHOOL.
speech.line: Where be your ribands, maids? Swim with your bodies,
And carry it sweetly and deliverly,
And now and then a favor and a frisk.

speech.speaker: NELL.
speech.line: Let us alone, sir.

speech.speaker: SCHOOL.
speech.line: Where’s the rest o’ th’ music?

speech.speaker: 3. COUN.
speech.line: Dispers’d as you commanded.

speech.speaker: SCHOOL.
speech.line: Couple then,
And see what’s wanting. Where’s the Bavian?
My friend, carry your tail without offense
Or scandal to the ladies; and be sure
You tumble with audacity and manhood,
And when you bark, do it with judgment.

speech.speaker: BAVIAN.
speech.line: Yes, sir.

speech.speaker: SCHOOL.
speech.line: Quo usque tandem? Here is a woman wanting.

speech.speaker: 4. COUN.
speech.line: We may go whistle; all the fat’s i’ th’ fire.

speech.speaker: SCHOOL.
speech.line: We have, as learned authors utter, wash’d a tile,
We have been fatuus, and labored vainly.

speech.speaker: 2. COUN.
speech.line: This is that scornful piece, that scurvy hilding,
That gave her promise faithfully she would
Be here, Cicely the sempster’s daughter.
The next gloves that I give her shall be dogskin;
Nay, and she fail me once—You can tell, Arcas,
She swore by wine and bread she would not break.

speech.speaker: SCHOOL.
speech.line: An eel and woman,
A learned poet says, unless by th’ tail
And with thy teeth thou hold, will either fail.
In manners this was false position.

speech.speaker: 1. COUN.
speech.line: A fire ill take her! Does she flinch now?

speech.speaker: 3. COUN.
speech.line: What
Shall we determine, sir?

speech.speaker: SCHOOL.
speech.line: Nothing,
Our business is become a nullity,
Yea, and a woeful and a piteous nullity.

speech.speaker: 4. COUN.
speech.line: Now when the credit of our town lay on it,
Now to be frampal, now to piss o’ th’ nettle!
Go thy ways, I’ll remember thee, I’ll fit thee!

scene.line: “The George Alow came from the south,
From the coast of Barbary-a;
And there he met with brave gallants of war,
By one, by two, by three-a.
Well hail’d, well hail’d, you jolly gallants!
And whither now are you bound-a?
O, let me have your company
Till I come to the sound-a.”
“There was three fools fell out about an howlet:
The one said it was an owl,
The other he said nay,
The third he said it was a hawk,
And her bells were cut away.”

speech.speaker: 3. COUN.
speech.line: There’s a dainty mad woman, master,
Comes i’ th’ nick, as mad as a March hare.
If we can get her dance, we are made again.
I warrant her, she’ll do the rarest gambols.

speech.speaker: 1. COUN.
speech.line: A mad woman? We are made, boys!

speech.speaker: SCHOOL.
speech.line: And are you mad, good woman?

speech.speaker: DAUGH.
speech.line: I would be sorry else.
Give me your hand.

speech.speaker: SCHOOL.
speech.line: Why?

speech.speaker: DAUGH.
speech.line: I can tell your fortune.
You are a fool. Tell ten—I have pos’d him. Buzz!
Friend, you must eat no white bread; if you do,
Your teeth will bleed extremely. Shall we dance ho?
I know you, y’ are a tinker. Sirrah tinker,
Stop no more holes but what you should.

speech.speaker: SCHOOL.
speech.line: A tinker, damsel?

speech.speaker: DAUGH.
speech.line: Or a conjurer.
Raise me a devil now, and let him play
Qui passa o’ th’ bells and bones.

speech.speaker: SCHOOL.
speech.line: Go take her,
And fluently persuade her to a peace.

line.latin: “Et opus exegi, quod nec Jovis ira, nec ignis”—

speech.line: Strike up, and lead her in.

speech.speaker: 2. COUN.
speech.line: Come, lass, let’s trip it.

speech.speaker: DAUGH.
speech.line: I’ll lead.

speech.speaker: 3. COUN.
speech.line: Do, do.

speech.speaker: SCHOOL.
speech.line: Persuasively and cunningly.
Pallas inspire me!

stagedir.dir: Enter Theseus, Pirithous, Hippolyta, Emilia, Arcite, and Train.

scene.line: Ladies, if we have been merry,
And have pleas’d ye with a derry,
And a derry, and a down,
Say the schoolmaster’s no clown.
Duke, if we have pleas’d thee too
And have done as good boys should do,
Give us but a tree or twain
For a Maypole, and again,
Ere another year run out,
We’ll make thee laugh and all this rout.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Take twenty, domine.—How does my sweet heart?

speech.speaker: HIP.
speech.line: Never so pleas’d, sir.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: ’Twas an excellent dance, and for a preface,
I never heard a better.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Schoolmaster, I thank you.
One see ’em all rewarded.

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: And here’s something
To paint your pole withal.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Now to our sports again.

speech.speaker: SCHOOL.
speech.line: May the stag thou hunt’st stand long,
And thy dogs be swift and strong!
May they kill him without lets,
And the ladies eat his dowsets!

stagedir.dir: Exeunt Theseus and his company. Wind horns.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: About this hour my cousin gave his faith
To visit me again, and with him bring
Two swords and two good armors. If he fail,
He’s neither man nor soldier. When he left me,
I did not think a week could have restor’d
My lost strength to me, I was grown so low
And crestfall’n with my wants. I thank thee, Arcite,
Thou art yet a fair foe; and I feel myself,
With this refreshing, able once again
To out-dure danger. To delay it longer
Would make the world think, when it comes to hearing,
That I lay fatting like a swine, to fight,
And not a soldier: therefore this blest morning
Shall be the last; and that sword he refuses,
If it but hold, I kill him with. ’Tis justice.
So, love and fortune for me!

stagedir.dir: Enter Arcite with armors and swords.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Lo, cousin, lo, our folly has undone us.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Why?

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: This is the Duke, a-hunting as I told you.
If we be found, we are wretched. O, retire
For honor’s sake, and safely presently
Into your bush again, sir. We shall find
Too many hours to die in, gentle cousin.
If you be seen, you perish instantly
For breaking prison, and I, if you reveal me,
For my contempt. Then all the world will scorn us,
And say we had a noble difference,
But base disposers of it.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: No, no, cousin,
I will no more be hidden, nor put off
This great adventure to a second trial.
I know your cunning, and I know your cause.
He that faints now, shame take him! Put thyself
Upon thy present guard—

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: You are not mad?

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Or I will make th’ advantage of this hour
Mine own; and what to come shall threaten me
I fear less than my fortune. Know, weak cousin,
I love Emilia, and in that I’ll bury
Thee and all crosses else.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Then come what can come,
Thou shalt know, Palamon, I dare as well
Die as discourse or sleep. Only this fears me,
The law will have the honor of our ends.
Have at thy life!

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Look to thine own well, Arcite.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: What ignorant and mad malicious traitors
Are you, that ’gainst the tenor of my laws
Are making battle, thus like knights appointed,
Without my leave and officers of arms?
By Castor, both shall die.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Hold thy word, Theseus.
We are certainly both traitors, both despisers
Of thee and of thy goodness. I am Palamon,
That cannot love thee, he that broke thy prison—
Think well what that deserves; and this is Arcite,
A bolder traitor never trod thy ground,
A falser nev’r seem’d friend. This is the man
Was begg’d and banish’d, this is he contemns thee
And what thou dar’st do; and in this disguise,
Against thy own edict, follows thy sister,
That fortunate bright star, the fair Emilia,
Whose servant (if there be a right in seeing,
And first bequeathing of the soul to) justly
I am, and which is more, dares think her his.
This treachery, like a most trusty lover,
I call’d him now to answer. If thou be’st,
As thou art spoken, great and virtuous,
The true decider of all injuries,
Say, “Fight again!” and thou shalt see me, Theseus,
Do such a justice thou thyself wilt envy.
Then take my life, I’ll woo thee to’t.

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: O heaven,
What more than man is this!

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: I have sworn.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: We seek not
Thy breath of mercy, Theseus. ’Tis to me
A thing as soon to die as thee to say it,
And no more mov’d. Where this man calls me traitor,
Let me say thus much: if in love be treason
In service of so excellent a beauty,
As I love most, and in that faith will perish,
As I have brought my life here to confirm it,
As I have serv’d her truest, worthiest,
As I dare kill this cousin that denies it,
So let me be most traitor, and ye please me.
For scorning thy edict, Duke, ask that lady
Why she is fair, and why her eyes command me
Stay here to love her; and if she say “traitor,”
I am a villain fit to lie unburied.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Thou shalt have pity of us both, O Theseus,
If unto neither thou show mercy. Stop,
As thou art just, thy noble ear against us;
As thou art valiant, for thy cousin’s soul,
Whose twelve strong labors crown his memory,
Let ’s die together, at one instant, Duke.
Only a little let him fall before me,
That I may tell my soul he shall not have her.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: I grant your wish, for to say true, your cousin
Has ten times more offended, for I gave him
More mercy than you found, sir, your offenses
Being no more than his. None here speak for ’em,
For ere the sun set, both shall sleep forever.

speech.speaker: HIP.
speech.line: Alas, the pity! Now or never, sister,
Speak, not to be denied. That face of yours
Will bear the curses else of after-ages
For these lost cousins.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: In my face, dear sister,
I find no anger to ’em, nor no ruin:
The misadventure of their own eyes kill ’em;
Yet that I will be woman, and have pity,
My knees shall grow to th’ ground but I’ll get mercy.
Help me, dear sister, in a deed so virtuous
The powers of all women will be with us.
Most royal brother—

speech.speaker: HIP.
speech.line: Sir, by our tie of marriage—

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: By your own spotless honor—

speech.speaker: HIP.
speech.line: By that faith,
That fair hand, and that honest heart you gave me—

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: By that you would have pity in another,
By your own virtues infinite—

speech.speaker: HIP.
speech.line: By valor,
By all the chaste nights I have ever pleas’d you—

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: These are strange conjurings.

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: Nay then I’ll in too.
By all our friendship, sir, by all our dangers,
By all you love most—wars, and this sweet lady—

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: By that you would have trembled to deny
A blushing maid—

speech.speaker: HIP.
speech.line: By your own eyes, by strength,
In which you swore I went beyond all women,
Almost all men, and yet I yielded, Theseus—

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: To crown all this, by your most noble soul,
Which cannot want due mercy, I beg first.

speech.speaker: HIP.
speech.line: Next hear my prayers.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Last let me entreat, sir.

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: For mercy.

speech.speaker: HIP.
speech.line: Mercy.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Mercy on these princes.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Ye make my faith reel. Say I felt
Compassion to ’em both, how would you place it?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Upon their lives; but with their banishments.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: You are a right woman, sister, you have pity,
But want the understanding where to use it.
If you desire their lives, invent a way
Safer than banishment. Can these two live,
And have the agony of love about ’em,
And not kill one another? Every day
They’ld fight about you; hourly bring your honor
In public question with their swords. Be wise then
And here forget ’em; it concerns your credit
And my oath equally. I have said they die;
Better they fall by th’ law than one another.
Bow not my honor.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: O my noble brother,
That oath was rashly made, and in your anger,
Your reason will not hold it. If such vows
Stand for express will, all the world must perish.
Beside, I have another oath ’gainst yours,
Of more authority, I am sure more love,
Not made in passion neither, but good heed.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: What is it, sister?

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: Urge it home, brave lady.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: That you would nev’r deny me any thing
Fit for my modest suit and your free granting.
I tie you to your word now; if ye fall in’t,
Think how you maim your honor
(For now I am set a-begging, sir, I am deaf
To all but your compassion), how their lives
Might breed the ruin of my name; opinion,
Shall any thing that loves me perish for me?
That were a cruel wisdom. Do men proin
The straight young boughs that blush with thousand blossoms,
Because they may be rotten? O Duke Theseus,
The goodly mothers that have groan’d for these,
And all the longing maids that ever lov’d,
If your vow stand, shall curse me and my beauty,
And in their funeral songs for these two cousins
Despise my cruelty, and cry woe worth me,
Till I am nothing but the scorn of women.
For heaven’s sake save their lives, and banish ’em.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: On what conditions?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Swear ’em never more
To make me their contention, or to know me,
To tread upon thy dukedom, and to be,
Where ever they shall travel, ever strangers
To one another.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: I’ll be cut a-pieces
Before I take this oath. Forget I love her?
O all ye gods, despise me then. Thy banishment
I not mislike, so we may fairly carry
Our swords and cause along; else, never trifle,
But take our lives, Duke. I must love, and will,
And for that love must and dare kill this cousin,
On any piece the earth has.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Will you, Arcite,
Take these conditions?

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: He’s a villain then.

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: These are men!

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: No, never. Duke. ’Tis worse to me than begging
To take my life so basely. Though I think
I never shall enjoy her, yet I’ll preserve
The honor of affection, and die for her,
Make death a devil.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: What may be done? For now I feel compassion.

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: Let it not fall again, sir.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Say, Emilia,
If one of them were dead, as one must, are you
Content to take th’ other to your husband?
They cannot both enjoy you. They are princes
As goodly as your own eyes, and as noble
As ever fame yet spoke of. Look upon ’em
And if you can love, end this difference.
I give consent.—Are you content too, princes?

speech.speaker: BOTH. ARC. AND PAL.
speech.line: With all our souls.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: He that she refuses
Must die then.

speech.speaker: BOTH. ARC. AND PAL.
speech.line: Any death thou canst invent, Duke.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: If I fall from that mouth, I fall with favor,
And lovers yet unborn shall bless my ashes.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: If she refuse me, yet my grave will wed me,
And soldiers sing my epitaph.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Make choice then.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: I cannot, sir, they are both too excellent:
For me, a hair shall never fall of these men.

speech.speaker: HIP.
speech.line: What will become of ’em?

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Thus I ordain it,
And by mine honor, once again it stands,
Or both shall die: you shall both to your country,
And each within this month, accompanied
With three fair knights, appear again in this place,
In which I’ll plant a pyramid; and whether,
Before us that are here, can force his cousin
By fair and knightly strength to touch the pillar,
He shall enjoy her; the other lose his head,
And all his friends; nor shall he grudge to fall,
Nor think he dies with interest in this lady.
Will this content ye?

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Yes. Here, cousin Arcite,
I am friends again till that hour.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: I embrace ye.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Are you content, sister?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Yes, I must, sir,
Else both miscarry.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Come shake hands again then,
And take heed, as you are gentlemen, this quarrel
Sleep till the hour prefix’d, and hold your course.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: We dare not fail thee, Theseus.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Come, I’ll give ye
Now usage like to princes and to friends.
When ye return, who wins I’ll settle here;
Who loses, yet I’ll weep upon his bier.

scene.scenelocation: Athens. A room in the prison.

speech.speaker: 2. FRIEND.
speech.line: Be of good comfort, man; I bring you news,
Good news.

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: They are welcome.

speech.speaker: 2. FRIEND.
speech.line: Palamon has clear’d you,
And got your pardon, and discover’d how
And by whose means he escap’d, which was your daughter’s,
Whose pardon is procur’d too; and the prisoner—
Not to be held ungrateful to her goodness—
Has given a sum of money to her marriage,
A large one, I’ll assure you.

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: Ye are a good man
And ever bring good news.

speech.speaker: 1. FRIEND.
speech.line: How was it ended?

speech.speaker: 2. FRIEND.
speech.line: Why, as it should be: they that nev’r begg’d
But they prevail’d, had their suits fairly granted:
The prisoners have their lives.

speech.speaker: 1. FRIEND.
speech.line: I knew ’twould be so.

speech.speaker: 2. FRIEND.
speech.line: But there be new conditions, which you’ll hear of
At better time.

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: I hope they are good.

speech.speaker: 2. FRIEND.
speech.line: They are honorable,
How good they’ll prove, I know not.

speech.speaker: 1. FRIEND.
speech.line: ’Twill be known.

scene.line: Here they are.

speech.speaker: DAUGH.
speech.line: “O fair, O sweet,” etc.

speech.speaker: JAIL. BROTH.
speech.line: You must ev’n take it patiently.

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: ’Tis true.

speech.speaker: DAUGH.
speech.line: Good ev’n, good men. Pray did you ever hear
Of one young Palamon?

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: Yes, wench, we know him.

speech.speaker: DAUGH.
speech.line: Is’t not a fine young gentleman?

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: ’Tis, love.

speech.speaker: JAIL. BROTH.
speech.line: By no mean cross her, she is then distemper’d
Far worse than now she shows.

speech.speaker: 1. FRIEND.
speech.line: Yes, he’s a fine man.

speech.speaker: DAUGH.
speech.line: O, is he so? You have a sister?

speech.speaker: 1. FRIEND.
speech.line: Yes.

speech.speaker: DAUGH.
speech.line: But she shall never have him, tell her so,
For a trick that I know. Y’ had best look to her,
For if she see him once, she’s gone—she’s done,
And undone in an hour. All the young maids
Of our town are in love with him, but I laugh at ’em
And let ’em all alone. Is’t not a wise course?

speech.speaker: 1. FRIEND.
speech.line: Yes.

speech.speaker: DAUGH.
speech.line: There is at least two hundred now with child by him—
There must be four. Yet I keep close for all this,
Close as a cockle. And all these must be boys,
He has the trick on’t; and at ten years old
They must be all gelt for musicians,
And sing the wars of Theseus.

speech.speaker: 2. FRIEND.
speech.line: This is strange.

speech.speaker: DAUGH.
speech.line: As ever you heard, but say nothing.

speech.speaker: 1. FRIEND.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: DAUGH.
speech.line: They come from all parts of the dukedom to him.
I’ll warrant ye he had not so few last night
As twenty to dispatch. He’ll tickle’t up
In two hours, if his hand be in.

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: She’s lost
Past all cure.

speech.speaker: JAIL. BROTH.
speech.line: Heaven forbid, man!

speech.speaker: DAUGH.
speech.line: “When Cynthia with her borrowed light,” etc.

stagedir.dir: Enter Emilia alone, with two pictures.

scene.line: How now, sir?

speech.speaker: GENT.
speech.line: From the noble Duke your brother,
Madam, I bring you news. The knights are come.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: To end the quarrel?

speech.speaker: GENT.
speech.line: Yes.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Would I might end first!
What sins have I committed, chaste Diana,
That my unspotted youth must now be soil’d
With blood of princes? And my chastity
Be made the altar where the lives of lovers—
Two greater and two better never yet
Made mothers joy—must be the sacrifice
To my unhappy beauty?

stagedir.dir: Enter Theseus, Hippolyta, Pirithous, and Attendants.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: From whence come you, sir?

speech.speaker: 1. MESS.
speech.line: From the knights.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Pray speak,
You that have seen them, what they are.

speech.speaker: 1. MESS.
speech.line: I will, sir,
And truly what I think. Six braver spirits
Than these they have brought (if we judge by the outside)
I never saw nor read of. He that stands
In the first place with Arcite, by his seeming
Should be a stout man, by his face a prince
(His very looks so say him), his complexion
Nearer a brown than black; stern, and yet noble,
Which shows him hardy, fearless, proud of dangers.
The circles of his eyes show fire within him,
And as a heated lion, so he looks;
His hair hangs long behind him, black and shining
Like ravens’ wings; his shoulders broad and strong,
Arm’d long and round, and on his thigh a sword
Hung by a curious baldrick, when he frowns
To seal his will with. Better, o’ my conscience,
Was never soldier’s friend.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Thou hast well describ’d him.

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: Yet a great deal short,
Methinks, of him that’s first with Palamon.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Pray speak him, friend.

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: I guess he is a prince too,
And if it may be, greater; for his show
Has all the ornament of honor in’t.
He’s somewhat bigger than the knight he spoke of,
But of a face far sweeter; his complexion
Is, as a ripe grape, ruddy. He has felt
Without doubt what he fights for, and so apter
To make this cause his own. In ’s face appears
All the fair hopes of what he undertakes,
And when he’s angry, then a settled valor
(Not tainted with extremes) runs through his body,
And guides his arm to brave things. Fear he cannot,
He shows no such soft temper. His head’s yellow,
Hard-hair’d, and curl’d, thick twin’d like ivy-tods,
Not to undo with thunder. In his face
The livery of the warlike maid appears,
Pure red and white, for yet no beard has blest him;
And in his rolling eyes sits victory,
As if she ever meant to crown his valor.
His nose stands high, a character of honor;
His red lips, after fights, are fit for ladies.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Must these men die too?

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: When he speaks, his tongue
Sounds like a trumpet. All his lineaments
Are as a man would wish ’em, strong and clean.
He wears a well-steel’d axe, the staff of gold.
His age some five and twenty.

speech.speaker: 1. MESS.
speech.line: There’s another,
A little man, but of a tough soul, seeming
As great as any. Fairer promises
In such a body yet I never look’d on.

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: O, he that’s freckle-fac’d?

speech.speaker: 1. MESS.
speech.line: The same, my lord.
Are they not sweet ones?

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: Yes, they are well.

speech.speaker: 1. MESS.
speech.line: Methinks,
Being so few and well dispos’d, they show
Great and fine art in nature. He’s white-hair’d,
Not wanton white, but such a manly color
Next to an auburn; tough and nimble set,
Which shows an active soul; his arms are brawny,
Lin’d with strong sinews; to the shoulder-piece
Gently they swell, like women new conceiv’d,
Which speaks him prone to labor, never fainting
Under the weight of arms; stout-hearted, still,
But when he stirs, a tiger. He’s grey-ey’d,
Which yields compassion where he conquers; sharp
To spy advantages, and where he finds ’em,
He’s swift to make ’em his. He does no wrongs,
Nor takes none. He’s round-fac’d, and when he smiles
He shows a lover, when he frowns, a soldier.
About his head he wears the winner’s oak,
And in it stuck the favor of his lady.
His age some six and thirty. In his hand
He bears a charging-staff emboss’d with silver.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Are they all thus?

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: They are all the sons of honor.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Now as I have a soul I long to see ’em.
Lady, you shall see men fight now.

speech.speaker: HIP.
speech.line: I wish it,
But not the cause, my lord. They would show
Bravely about the titles of two kingdoms.
’Tis pity love should be so tyrannous.
O my soft-hearted sister, what think you?
Weep not, till they weep blood. Wench, it must be.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: You have steel’d ’em with your beauty.—Honor’d friend,
To you I give the field; pray order it,
Fitting the persons that must use it.

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: Yes, sir.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Come, I’ll go visit ’em. I cannot stay—
Their fame has fir’d me so—till they appear.
Good friend, be royal.

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: There shall want no bravery.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Poor wench, go weep, for whosoever wins
Loses a noble cousin for thy sins.

scene.line: Look where she comes, you shall perceive her behavior.

speech.speaker: DAUGH.
speech.line: I have forgot it quite; the burden on’t was “Down-a, down-a,” and penn’d by no worse man than Giraldo, Emilia’s schoolmaster. He’s as fantastical, too, as ever he may go upon ’s legs, for in the next world will Dido see Palamon, and then will she be out of love with Aeneas.

speech.speaker: DOCT.
speech.line: What stuff’s here? Poor soul!

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: Ev’n thus all day long.

speech.speaker: DAUGH.
speech.line: Now for this charm that I told you of, you must bring a piece of silver on the tip of your tongue, or no ferry. Then, if it be your chance to come where the blessed spirits—as there’s a sight now! We maids that have our livers perish’d, crack’d to pieces with love, we shall come there, and do nothing all day long but pick flowers with Proserpine. Then will I make Palamon a nosegay, then let him mark me—then—

speech.speaker: DOCT.
speech.line: How prettily she’s amiss! Note her a little further.

speech.speaker: DAUGH.
speech.line: Faith, I’ll tell you; sometime we go to barley-break, we of the blessed. Alas, ’tis a sore life they have i’ th’ tother place, such burning, frying, boiling, hissing, howling, chatt’ring, cursing! O, they have shrowd measure! Take heed: if one be mad, or hang or drown themselves, thither they go—Jupiter bless us!—and there shall we be put in a cauldron of lead and usurers’ grease, amongst a whole million of cutpurses, and there boil like a gammon of bacon that will never be enough.

speech.speaker: DAUGH.
speech.line: Lords and courtiers that have got maids with child, they are in this place. They shall stand in fire up to the nav’l, and in ice up to th’ heart, and there th’ offending part burns, and the deceiving part freezes: in troth a very grievous punishment, as one would think, for such a trifle. Believe me, one would marry a leprous witch to be rid on’t, I’ll assure you.

speech.speaker: DOCT.
speech.line: How she continues this fancy! ’Tis not an engraff’d madness, but a most thick and profound melancholy.

speech.speaker: DAUGH.
speech.line: To hear there a proud lady and a proud city-wife howl together! I were a beast and I’ld call it good sport. One cries, “O, this smoke!” th’ other, “This fire!” One cries, “O, that ever I did it behind the arras!” and then howls; th’ other curses a suing fellow and her garden-house.

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: What think you of her, sir?

speech.speaker: DOCT.
speech.line: I think she has a perturb’d mind, which I cannot minister to.

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: Alas, what then?

speech.speaker: DOCT.
speech.line: Understand you she ever affected any man ere she beheld Palamon?

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: I was once, sir, in great hope she had fix’d her liking on this gentleman, my friend.

speech.speaker: WOOER.
speech.line: I did think so too, and would account I had a great penn’worth on’t to give half my state that both she and I at this present stood unfeignedly on the same terms.

speech.speaker: DOCT.
speech.line: That intemp’rate surfeit of her eye hath distemper’d the other senses. They may return and settle again to execute their preordain’d faculties, but they are now in a most extravagant vagary. This you must do: confine her to a place where the light may rather seem to steal in than be permitted. Take upon you, young sir her friend, the name of Palamon, say you come to eat with her, and to commune of love. This will catch her attention, for this her mind beats upon; other objects that are inserted ’tween her mind and eye become the pranks and friskins of her madness. Sing to her such green songs of love as she says Palamon hath sung in prison. Come to her, stuck in as sweet flowers as the season is mistress of, and thereto make an addition of some other compounded odors which are grateful to the sense. All this shall become Palamon, for Palamon can sing, and Palamon is sweet, and ev’ry good thing. Desire to eat with her, carve her, drink to her, and still among intermingle your petition of grace and acceptance into her favor. Learn what maids have been her companions and play-feres, and let them repair to her with Palamon in their mouths, and appear with tokens, as if they suggested for him. It is a falsehood she is in, which is with falsehoods to be combated. This may bring her to eat, to sleep, and reduce what’s now out of square in her into their former law and regiment. I have seen it approv’d, how many times I know not, but to make the number more I have great hope in this. I will, between the passages of this project, come in with my appliance. Let us put it in execution; and hasten the success, which doubt not will bring forth comfort.

scene.scenelocation: Before the Temples of Mars, Venus, and Diana.

stagedir.dir: Three altars erected—to Mars, Venus, and Diana. Flourish. Enter Theseus, Pirithous, Hippolyta, Attendants.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Now let ’em enter, and before the gods
Tender their holy prayers. Let the temples
Burn bright with sacred fires, and the altars
In hallowed clouds commend their swelling incense
To those above us. Let no due be wanting;
They have a noble work in hand will honor
The very powers that love ’em.

stagedir.dir: Flourish of cornets. Enter Palamon and Arcite and their Knights.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: The glass is running now that cannot finish
Till one of us expire. Think you but thus,
That were there aught in me which strove to show
Mine enemy in this business, were’t one eye
Against another, arm oppress’d by arm,
I would destroy th’ offender, coz, I would,
Though parcel of myself. Then from this gather
How I should tender you.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: I am in labor
To push your name, your ancient love, our kindred,
Out of my memory; and i’ th’ self-same place
To seat something I would confound. So hoist we
The sails that must these vessels port even where
The heavenly limiter pleases.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: You speak well.
Before I turn, let me embrace thee, cousin.
This I shall never do again.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: One farewell.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Why, let it be so; farewell, coz.

speech.speaker: ARC.
speech.line: Farewell, sir.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Our stars must glister with new fire, or be
Today extinct. Our argument is love,
Which if the goddess of it grant, she gives
Victory too. Then blend your spirits with mine,
You whose free nobleness do make my cause
Your personal hazard. To the goddess Venus
Commend we our proceeding, and implore
Her power unto our party.

stagedir.dir: Here they advance to the altar of Venus, and fall on their faces; then kneel, as formerly.

speech.line: Hail, sovereign queen of secrets, who hast power
To call the fiercest tyrant from his rage,
And weep unto a girl; that hast the might,
Even with an eye-glance, to choke Mars’s drum
And turn th’ alarm to whispers; that canst make
A cripple flourish with his crutch, and cure him
Before Apollo; that mayst force the king
To be his subject’s vassal, and induce
Stale gravity to dance; the poll’d bachelor,
Whose youth, like wanton boys through bonfires,
Have skipp’d thy flame, at seventy thou canst catch,
And make him, to the scorn of his hoarse throat,
Abuse young lays of love. What godlike power
Hast thou not power upon? To Phoebus thou
Add’st flames, hotter than his; the heavenly fires
Did scorch his mortal son, thine him. The huntress
All moist and cold, some say, began to throw
Her bow away, and sigh. Take to thy grace
Me thy vow’d soldier, who do bear thy yoke
As ’twere a wreath of roses, yet is heavier
Than lead itself, stings more than nettles. I
Have never been foul-mouth’d against thy law,
Nev’r reveal’d secret, for I knew none—would not,
Had I kenn’d all that were. I never practiced
Upon man’s wife, nor would the libels read
Of liberal wits. I never at great feasts
Sought to betray a beauty, but have blush’d
At simp’ring sirs that did. I have been harsh
To large confessors, and have hotly ask’d them
If they had mothers; I had one, a woman,
And women ’twere they wrong’d. I knew a man
Of eighty winters—this I told them—who
A lass of fourteen brided. ’Twas thy power
To put life into dust: the aged cramp
Had screw’d his square foot round,
The gout had knit his fingers into knots,
Torturing convulsions from his globy eyes
Had almost drawn their spheres, that what was life
In him seem’d torture. This anatomy
Had by his young fair fere a boy, and I
Believ’d it was his, for she swore it was,
And who would not believe her? Brief, I am
To those that prate and have done, no companion;
To those that boast and have not, a defier;
To those that would and cannot, a rejoicer.
Yea, him I do not love that tells close offices
The foulest way, nor names concealments in
The boldest language. Such a one I am,
And vow that lover never yet made sigh
Truer than I. O then, most soft sweet goddess,
Give me the victory of this question, which
Is true love’s merit, and bless me with a sign
Of thy great pleasure.

stagedir.dir: Here music is heard; doves are seen to flutter. They fall again upon their faces, then on their knees.

speech.line: O thou that from eleven to ninety reign’st
In mortal bosoms, whose chase is this world,
And we in herds thy game, I give thee thanks
For this fair token, which being laid unto
Mine innocent true heart, arms in assurance
My body to this business.—Let us rise
And bow before the goddess. Time comes on.

scene.scenelocation: A darkened room in the prison.

stagedir.dir: Enter Doctor, Jailer, and Wooer in habit of Palamon.

speech.speaker: DOCT.
speech.line: Go, go!
You fathers are fine fools. Her honesty!
And we should give her physic till we find that—

speech.speaker: WOOER.
speech.line: Why, do you think she is not honest, sir?

speech.speaker: DOCT.
speech.line: How old is she?

speech.speaker: WOOER.
speech.line: She’s eighteen.

speech.speaker: DOCT.
speech.line: She may be,
But that’s all one, ’tis nothing to our purpose.
What e’er her father says, if you perceive
Her mood inclining that way that I spoke of,
Videlicet, the way of flesh—you have me?

speech.speaker: WOOER.
speech.line: Yet very well, sir.

speech.speaker: DOCT.
speech.line: Please her appetite,
And do it home; it cures her ipso facto
The melancholy humor that infects her.

speech.speaker: WOOER.
speech.line: I am of your mind, doctor.

speech.speaker: 1. MESS.
speech.line: What do you here? You’ll lose the noblest sight
That ev’r was seen.

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: Are they i’ th’ field?

speech.speaker: 1. MESS.
speech.line: They are.
You bear a charge there too.

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: I’ll away straight.
I must ev’n leave you here.

speech.speaker: DOCT.
speech.line: Nay, we’ll go with you,
I will not lose the fight.

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: How did you like her?

speech.speaker: DOCT.
speech.line: I’ll warrant you within these three or four days
I’ll make her right again.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: I’ll no step further.

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: Will you lose this sight?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: I had rather see a wren hawk at a fly
Than this decision. Ev’ry blow that falls
Threats a brave life, each stroke laments
The place whereon it falls, and sounds more like
A bell than blade. I will stay here,
It is enough my hearing shall be punish’d
With what shall happen—’gainst the which there is
No deafing—but to hear, not taint mine eye
With dread sights it may shun.

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: Sir, my good lord,
Your sister will no further.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: O, she must.
She shall see deeds of honor in their kind
Which sometime show well, pencill’d. Nature now
Shall make and act the story, the belief
Both seal’d with eye and ear. You must be present,
You are the victor’s meed, the price and garland
To crown the question’s title.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Pardon me,
If I were there, I’ld wink.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: You must be there;
This trial is as ’twere i’ th’ night, and you
The only star to shine.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: I am extinct,
There is but envy in that light which shows
The one the other. Darkness, which ever was
The dam of Horror, who does stand accurs’d
Of many mortal millions, may even now,
By casting her black mantle over both,
That neither could find other, get herself
Some part of a good name, and many a murder
Set off whereto she’s guilty.

speech.speaker: HIP.
speech.line: You must go.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: In faith, I will not.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Why, the knights must kindle
Their valor at your eye. Know, of this war
You are the treasure, and must needs be by
To give the service pay.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Sir, pardon me,
The title of a kingdom may be tried
Out of itself.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Well, well then, at your pleasure.
Those that remain with you could wish their office
To any of their enemies.

speech.speaker: HIP.
speech.line: Farewell, sister,
I am like to know your husband ’fore yourself
By some small start of time. He whom the gods
Do of the two know best, I pray them he
Be made your lot.
Hark how yon spurs to spirit do incite
The princes to their proof! Arcite may win me,
And yet may Palamon wound Arcite to
The spoiling of his figure. O, what pity
Enough for such a chance? If I were by,
I might do hurt, for they would glance their eyes
Toward my seat, and in that motion might
Omit a ward, or forfeit an offense,
Which crav’d that very time. It is much better
I am not there. O, better never born
Than minister to such harm!

stagedir.dir: Cornets. A great cry and noise within, crying “A Palamon!”

speech.line: Poor servant, thou hast lost.
Upon my right side still I wore thy picture,
Palamon’s on the left. Why so, I know not;
I had no end in’t else; chance would have it so.
On the sinister side the heart lies; Palamon
Had the best-boding chance.

stagedir.dir: Another cry, and shout within, and cornets.

speech.line: This burst of clamor
Is sure th’ end o’ th’ combat.

stagedir.dir: Enter Theseus, Hippolyta, Pirithous, Arcite as victor, and Attendants, etc.

scene.scenelocation: A place near the Lists. A block prepared.

stagedir.dir: A block ready. Enter Palamon and his Knights pinion’d, Jailer, Executioner, etc., Guard.

scene.line: Ah ha, my friend, my friend,
Your gentle daughter gave me freedom once;
You’ll see’t done now forever. Pray how does she?
I heard she was not well; her kind of ill
Gave me some sorrow.

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: Sir, she’s well restor’d,
And to be married shortly.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: By my short life,
I am most glad on’t. ’Tis the latest thing
I shall be glad of, prithee tell her so.
Commend me to her, and to piece her portion
Tender her this.

speech.speaker: 1. KNIGHT.
speech.line: Nay, let’s be offerers all.

speech.speaker: 2. KNIGHT.
speech.line: Is it a maid?

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Verily I think so,
A right good creature, more to me deserving
Than I can quite or speak of.

speech.speaker: ALL KNIGHTS.
speech.line: Commend us to her.

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: The gods requite you all, and make her thankful!

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Adieu; and let my life be now as short
As my leave-taking.

speech.speaker: 3. KNIGHT.
speech.line: Lead, courageous cousin.

speech.speaker: BOTH 1. KNIGHT. AND 2. KNIGHT.
speech.line: We’ll follow cheerfully.

stagedir.dir: A great noise within crying “Run! Save! Hold!”

speech.speaker: 2. MESS.
speech.line: Hold, hold! O, hold, hold, hold!

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: Hold ho! It is a cursed haste you made
If you have done so quickly. Noble Palamon,
The gods will show their glory in a life
That thou art yet to lead.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Can that be, when
Venus I have said is false? How do things fare?

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: Arise, great sir, and give the tidings ear
That are most dearly sweet and bitter.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: What
Hath wak’d us from our dream?

speech.speaker: PIR.
speech.line: List then: your cousin,
Mounted upon a steed that Emily
Did first bestow on him—a black one, owing
Not a hair-worth of white, which some will say
Weakens his price, and many will not buy
His goodness with this note; which superstition
Here finds allowance—on this horse is Arcite
Trotting the stones of Athens, which the calkins
Did rather tell than trample; for the horse
Would make his length a mile, if’t pleas’d his rider
To put pride in him. As he thus went counting
The flinty pavement, dancing as ’twere to th’ music
His own hoofs made (for as they say from iron
Came music’s origin), what envious flint,
Cold as old Saturn, and like him possess’d
With fire malevolent, darted a spark,
Or what fierce sulphur else, to this end made,
I comment not—the hot horse, hot as fire,
Took toy at this, and fell to what disorder
His power could give his will, bounds, comes on end,
Forgets school-doing, being therein train’d,
And of kind manage; pig-like he whines
At the sharp rowel, which he frets at rather
Than any jot obeys; seeks all foul means
Of boist’rous and rough jad’ry, to disseat
His lord that kept it bravely. When nought serv’d,
When neither curb would crack, girth break, nor diff’ring plunges
Disroot his rider whence he grew, but that
He kept him ’tween his legs, on his hind hoofs
On end he stands,
That Arcite’s legs, being higher than his head,
Seem’d with strange art to hang. His victor’s wreath
Even then fell off his head; and presently
Backward the jade comes o’er, and his full poise
Becomes the rider’s load. Yet is he living,
But such a vessel ’tis that floats but for
The surge that next approaches. He much desires
To have some speech with you. Lo he appears.

stagedir.dir: Enter Theseus, Hippolyta, Emilia, Arcite in a chair.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: Thy brave soul seek Elysium!

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: I’ll close thine eyes, prince; blessed souls be with thee!
Thou art a right good man, and while I live,
This day I give to tears.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: And I to honor.

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: In this place first you fought; ev’n very here
I sund’red you. Acknowledge to the gods
Our thanks that you are living.
His part is play’d, and though it were too short,
He did it well; your day is length’ned, and
The blissful dew of heaven does arrouse you.
The powerful Venus well hath grac’d her altar,
And given you your love. Our master Mars
Hath vouch’d his oracle, and to Arcite gave
The grace of the contention So the deities
Have show’d due justice.—Bear this hence.

speech.speaker: PAL.
speech.line: O cousin,
That we should things desire which do cost us
The loss of our desire! That nought could buy
Dear love but loss of dear love!

speech.speaker: THE.
speech.line: Never fortune
Did play a subtler game. The conquer’d triumphs,
The victor has the loss; yet in the passage
The gods have been most equal. Palamon,
Your kinsman hath confess’d the right o’ th’ lady
Did lie in you, for you first saw her, and
Even then proclaim’d your fancy. He restor’d her
As your stol’n jewel, and desir’d your spirit
To send him hence forgiven. The gods my justice
Take from my hand, and they themselves become
The executioners. Lead your lady off;
And call your lovers from the stage of death,
Whom I adopt my friends. A day or two
Let us look sadly, and give grace unto
The funeral of Arcite, in whose end
The visages of bridegrooms we’ll put on
And smile with Palamon; for whom an hour,
But one hour since, I was as dearly sorry
As glad of Arcite; and am now as glad
As for him sorry. O you heavenly charmers,
What things you make of us! For what we lack
We laugh, for what we have are sorry, still
Are children in some kind. Let us be thankful
For that which is, and with you leave dispute
That are above our question. Let’s go off,
And bear us like the time.

speech.speaker: EPI.
speech.line: I would now ask ye how ye like the play,
But as it is with schoolboys, cannot say;
I am cruel fearful. Pray yet stay a while,
And let me look upon ye. No man smile?
Then it goes hard, I see. He that has
Lov’d a young handsome wench then, show his face—
’Tis strange if none be here—and if he will
Against his conscience, let him hiss, and kill
Our market. ’Tis in vain, I see, to stay ye;
Have at the worst can come, then! Now what say ye?
And yet mistake me not: I am not bold,
We have no such cause. If the tale we have told
(For ’tis no other) any way content ye
(For to that honest purpose it was meant ye),
We have our end; and ye shall have ere long
I dare say many a better, to prolong
Your old loves to us. We, and all our might,
Rest at your service. Gentlemen, good night.
